title: Patch Chat with the Playtest Team - 7.24
body:
Hey everyone and welcome to the Patch 7.24, the LAST PATCH OF SEASON 7! 


https://i.imgur.com/8sOD6mO.jpg

I’m Riot Novalas & I’m a QA Analyst on Riot’s Playtest Team, a group of high elo players who work on Core Gameplay playing new champions, reworks, balance tweaks, items, and map updates before they’re released. It’s our job to test the changes that our designers come up with and ensure that we’re introducing positive changes to League in terms of both balance and fun. 

Patch Chat serves as an opportunity for us to talk about the patches that come out every two weeks. You can find the most recent patch by following this link: 
https://na.leagueoflegends.com/en/news/game-updates/patch/patch-724-notes

There are a wide array of changes in this patch, focusing specifically on balance changes and runes changes. The healthbar update also hits live too! 

Ask us anything about the last patch of the season, our favorite rune builds on YOUR favorite champions, our likes and dislikes, how often we execute to jungle camps, and more!... Or feel free to just chat with us! We like people (mostly).

Disclaimer: We don’t have any insight into skins.

General question: how versed is the playtest team in their off-roles? Correct me if I'm wrong on this, but around 50% of the playtest team appear to be mid mains (based on non-scientific op.gg stalking) with the remaining 50% or so being split between the other four roles which to me seems rather imbalanced. Does this effect your ability to provide feedback on other champions or roles?

Depends on the individual playtesters. Some of us are fairly proficient off-role (I play 3 roles at a decent proficiency (mid/support/bot), Auberaun/RobertXLee play pretty much everything pretty well, and King Cobra cannot play ADC to save his life :D) and some of us play pretty much just a weird spattering of champions (Aesah and GangIeri)

I wouldn't say it affects our ability to give feedback too frequently -- but most notably it can be rough on individual playtesters when we have several changes to several champions in the same role (Riot Endstep is typically locked into the tank dungeon). We're working to improve on that front, however.

I'm sure you guys are going to be asked this question alot, but reading through the comments, I haven't seen an answer or comment on it yet.  Can you give us some kind of rationale behind why Sona needed the additional nerf, and why she's going to be getting yet another indirect nerf in the next patch?  

Her winrate dropped considerably after the first nerf, and it made her so much easier to punish in lane that she wasn't just a lane bully anymore.  But then you tack on the Aery nerf, the Q bonus damage and mana cost nerf which are currently live.  But it doesn't even stop there with the direct nerfs.  In the upcoming patch, she's getting hit with a round of indirect nerfs via the flat AP from Sorcery+Inspiration and the shield/heal strength from Forbidden Idol/Ardent Censer/Redemption.  

I guess what is making so many of us so upset is that none of the other champions were handled this harshly.  Even Leona and Miss Fortune, who both have great winrates right now.  Leona got a minor 20 damage off her TANK ability.  Miss Fortune hasn't had any nerfs.  Sona got an immediate hotfix, followed by 2 more rounds of nerfs.  And like so many other players here who try to be supportive of the decisions that Riot makes, I'm desperately trying to understand why this is necessary.  Why is this champion being gutted?  Why is Forbidden Idol being hit, when the tank supports are the most successful right now?  

Please, can you give us any insight?

Sure! Even after her previous nerfs statistically Sona was still a pretty big outlier. While her overall winrate was no longer insane, she was basically dead even with Leona and Taric for highest winrate in the role by our numbers, so she was certainly still very powerful. 
If we go beyond overall winrate and go to winrate with their best keystone however, there was clear evidence that Sona was still too strong. Her winrate with her best keystone (Kleptomancy) was over a full percent higher than any other Support, and was in fact the individual highest winrate Keystone/Champion combination at any role in the game.
I think these numbers indicate she has substantial room to be nerfed and still be a solid, even if no longer strong, champion.

Do you think it's evidence of balance issues with runes that klepto was her best choice, not aery? I mean you'd expect aery to be her best choice even though she likes sheen effects given that it amps both her attack and defense.

overall I wonder if klepto is too much of a stat driven mastery in that if a champion can use it well it just gives them a lot of free gold and stats over their opponents

This is tricky for Klepto, but I'd say it's ultimately not really a balance issue and somewhat our intended pattern for the rune.

The goal of the Inspiration tree in general is for it to offer unique playstyles that challenge you to optimize them in unconventional ways. As such we don't want the Runes in the path to be too generically powerful, i.e we'd prefer that they be powerful when you pick them in the correct situation and weak in the wrong situation, rather than be generally average or strong.

How this paradigm fits into Klepto means that there's a strong chance it is (and should be) the optimal choice for several champions who can best make use of it's paradigm. If we are trying to reward you for taking an Inspiration Keystone, and this Keystone revolves entirely around being able to cast a spell and auto, there wouldn't be much strategic or tactical gameplay to it if it's best users aren't getting significant reward for it. Ideally you are rewarded for taking this Keystone both on the champions who use it best, and against the champions who can punish you least for frequently auto attacking them (should be viable in solo lanes as a ranged champion against some melee).

Sona and Ezreal seem to be 2 of the clear cases who best fit the paradigm in practice, and since this is the lone requirement we are imposing on synergy with the Keystone, the remaining way we could make it stronger/weaker for them specifically is to adjust the loot table to give items that are less appealing to them. 

This is something we are thinking about, and it's possible we'll make more changes to how the loot table works going forward. Nothing planned on that immediately though.

To ultimately answer your question, it seems Sona is one of the best pattern fits for Klepto. Given that Inspiration Runes are supposed to sharply reward or punish you for optimizing (or failing to) around them, I think it makes sense that Klepto would outperform Aery on her.

Can you help a man out though?

As a Sona Mid player, this nerf hurts my early game like hell. It was already rough having to constantly expose myself for 100-150 damage pokes from people who can usually hit me back for twice that amount if they trade properly (at levels 1-5), now you've shaved off a major amount of it out. Not to mention it made my CSing way harder on top of that.

Lategame, AP Sona is still a goddess, but the early game is so punishing often the best i can manage is to not feed and pray my enemy laner doesn't go about murdering my allies after easily pushing the waves. I'm quite literally forced to rush Frost Queen's Claim as well as use Kleptomancy to maintain some form of reasonable income.

Some extra tankiness, or better ability to clear waves would be appreciated if there was a way to do it without breaking her support role.

> [{quoted}](name=Riot Hjarta,realm=NA,application-id=A7LBtoKc,discussion-id=KtbGvapw,comment-id=00130000,timestamp=2017-12-06T23:51:57.485+0000)

The mana nerf, if this is in response to the Sona-related question. The damage is pretty much fine, but Sona's laning is defined by her ability to AT LEAST fight. She can't have *an entire basic kit* of high mana spells. That's ridiculous.

I can't speak for HowPlayGAEM, but I've played (and mained) Sona off and on since Season 3.  She was my first support, and even after her first big rework, I didn't feel like she was this destroyed.  

The biggest issue I have with this changelist isn't the current nerf to her Q bonus damage, because I can understand bringing her damage back down a bit so that she's not overbearing in lane.  I can understand giving it a slightly higher mana cost, though that stings when supports don't have the ability to take mana regeneration runes or the meditation mastery.  At least Manaflow Band compensates for that some, and by completely changing my build order, I can deal with that.  

What I can't really get over is the continued nerf to her healing.  It was already the weakest heal in the game, compared to Soraka ( level 1 base heal 80 + 60% AP for 10%hp/50 mana ) and Nami ( level 1 base heal 65 + 30% AP for 70 mana ) at ( level 1 base heal 30 + 25% AP for 80 mana ).  The ability to have an increased heal on allies below 40% health was removed a while ago, which would have made a huge difference if that was still in play here.  The only thing that was saving her heal was the 8%/10% increased heal and shield strength that she gains from the Forbidden Idol/Ardent Censer/Redemption Items.  And those are being nerfed next patch.  The last nerfs hit her early game heal hard, the upcoming ones are going to hit her mid game heal hard.  She's turning into a healer with no heal.

Hey guys.

I'm a support main (filthy support main, as the boards would no doubt call me), and... the preseason feels really bad for me. In all previous seasons, and I'm not just talking about the Ardent meta where supports were regarded as being too strong, I felt like I had a real, tangible impact on the game. Even if I was behind, the utility I could provide if I coordinated well with my team could turn a losing game into a decisive victory, if I played really well.

Nowadays... no. League of Oneshot means that if the enemy team starts getting a lead, then if my carry gets jumped on while I'm playing Taric I can literally spam Q, W, try and hit E and start my R, to a Knight's Vow-bonded carry that I've just put Locket shield on, and they've _still_ blown up before my ult even lands. I have impact if my team as a whole is ahead, sure, but playing from behind feels -really- terrible now, which is something I've seen people other than supports complaining about, but I think it's pretty bad for us.

Any thoughts on this? Is there some secret trick I'm missing in preseason, or is it intentional that supports have less power? I've been a support main for a long time, but it's never felt this bad before.

So I'm also a filthy support main who also plays Taric!

1) I actually find the support role to be pretty impactful this preseason. Several supports (Sona, Leona, and Taric first come to mind) have been top outliers on the win rate leaderboards across all champions for the past 4 weeks. With Arcane Comet becoming more prevalent this patch, poke enchanters/mages have a lot of presence in deciding who wins bot lane.

2) Playing at a disadvantage typically feels pretty bad. Why do you think it feels worse now than before? I'm still having success keeping my team alive before Taric ult pops. 

3) Personally, I'm surprised you feel that the support role is the worst it's been. Locket rush every game back in S5 was pretty boring, and having the sole responsibility of buying green wards in S2 was REALLY crappy.

1) I understand that winrates are a useful metric, but at the same time I feel like they give a poor indication of how strong a role is as a whole. For instance, if toplane is a really weak role, some toplaners will still have higher winrates than others because despite their lack of agency they can still influence things a little more than others. By the same token supports are always going to have some favoured picks (Janna almost always has high winrate, for instance) regardless of whether the support role is OP as hell or completely useless in deciding a game outcome.

2) I think it feels worse because damage seems to be much higher than previously. As a recent example I came out of lane recently having gotten my Varus a few kills and a 50-60 cs lead. Then we tried to fight the toplane Jax who our Wukong had given a few kills to, and he one-shot Varus before I could even get my ult off. 2v1, we were ahead - in fairness, so was he, but I feel he shouldn't have so effortlessly murdered the two of us given we were also winning our lane. If you've got some tips for keeping people alive long enough for Taric ult to pop then I'd love you to tell me - I'm really getting tired of popping my ult and having three people including my tank go down before the ult lands!

3) Ever heard of the term "Boring, but Practical"? I feel that's the thing - I played back when support was just "ward-machine for the team", but I still felt my impact noticeably when I managed to light up the entire map and deny all the enemy vision. Locket rush was again, very homogeneous, but it felt good to save people when I did that. Nowadays, I feel like I have a number of bad choices. I can buy  Ardent first, or Knight's Vow first, or Locket first, but if I'm behind it feels like I can't keep up with what the enemy team are putting out. Meanwhile, when nearly every assassin rushes Duskblade, nearly every AP mid rushes Morellonomicon, nearly every bruiser rushes Cleaver and nearly every tank rushes Sunfire (Bramble, before last patch's changes), nobody complains about that being "boring" like they do with Locket-rush on supports, it's just what those champs build.

This is some great insight! Your comment on #3 in particular is a really eye opening perspective.

To be honest, timing your Taric ults requires a lot of intuition since every second counts. You need to gauge how much burst the enemy has, predict when they'll use it, and adjust accordingly. It might sound weird, but try going for ults that are a bit "too early". Don't forget to weave your passive between skills so you can spam 2 stack heals throughout the fight!
quite a few have called out sona's changes to be quite heavy handed. what was the playtesting team's thoughts behind this?

Personally, I felt like nerfing her was warranted.  She has been sitting at a high win rate for a while and she received a substantial amount of lane power from Klepto, Scorch, and Manaflow Band.  With that being said, I didn't really like the direction as it made her lane phase even more volatile.  She wasn't picked during pro play despite it being an Ardent Censer meta (my opinion is due to her lane phase being unreliable) and I feel like this pushes her even further away. 

From playtesting the changes, the mana nerfs were quite noticeable in the lane phase, but feels like it goes back to normal once you build Tear.
Do you think it's a good thing that a support needs to build a selfish item in order to support properly?

I still say they were heavy handed. And frankly not very well thought out for moving her power around. The fact that she needs 300 AP to break even means that she HAS to go the full AP route which is distinctly longer to build up to on a support income, even if you have klepto.

The better way to have done the nerf/change would have been to take away damage from the Q bolts and add it to the aura. That way she loses damage on the auto locking spell, and the only way she gains back that damage is properly landing Q->AA's.

A strong factor that pushes sona out of pro play (and a known hard counter for her patterns) is having a champ that can brute force all in's on her since she is literally the only utility support without hard CC on a basic ability, heck her only form of CC outside of the ult is on the powercord E. Late game you don't really have that luxury to control that, and almost no control for being able to use it reactively, part of the reason she is famously known as a faceroll champ. So outside of using more critical thinking for how to balance her kit, she frankly needs to be heavily updated, and could honestly be put on the list of champs in need of a mini GU like azir.

Caitlyn and Jhin still seem weak even after the footwork buffs. Do you have any plans for them in the future?

Unsure on Caitlyn. Numbers do suggest she may be weak but I personally think the Fleet Footwork buff was very substantial and she is maybe the best user, so I'd like to wait and see where she settles. In Kespa Cup the AD meta was also dominated by Sorcery primary poke AD's in lane (MF/Varus/Ashe/Jhin), so it's possible Caitlyn is just being crowded out by other champions filling her long range lane dominant niche better than her currently, which may change if we nerf Sorcery for AD's.

We don't all simultaneously keep up 100% with every possible change. There's too many potential changes all occurring at the same time for that to be feasible, so we have a division of labor system that sets up every changelist with a primary ticketholder who keeps up to date with the changes, any iterations on the changelist, and updates the team when necessary. That person is also the one that the designers who make the changelists keep in contact with for feedback, so in most cases it's easy to assign tickets by champion knowledge/lane/etc. - just assign the ticket to whoever has the most expertise in the area.
